Description: Low wooden stool with central rush webbing held in place by knots through holes in the wooden frame. Constructed from several pieces of wood, joined with tenons and dowels. Traces of gesso survive across the object surface.
Curator's comments: Published: Baker, Furniture in the Ancient World, (1966), p.135, pl.194. Killen, Ancient Egyptian Furniture, (1980), p.43. no.14, pl.65-6, fig.22.

A selection of stools from Deir el-Medina: Les artistes de pharaon (exhibition catalogue, Paris, 2003): 77 [6a-c]. Stools, seats and chairs were a common part of elite 18th dynasty burial assemblages (see Smith, MDAIK 48 [1992], 205-6).
